title.narrative: Inclusive humanitarian response for older men and women and people with disabilities affected by COVID-19 in South Sudan

description.narrative: HAI and HDC are able to influence the wider response through advocacy, campaigns, technical support and communications to ensure older people are considered and included.
Income and social protection are strengthened and older men and women and PwDs are able to cover their basic needs
Information and advice on COVID-19 is provided to older people and their carers in an inclusive and accessible way
Older men and women and people with disabilities are protected, feel safe and have full access to COVID-19 assistance

The intervention will promote an inclusive humanitarian response and community support through addressing the key needs (Food, WASH and Protection), and amplifying the voices of older persons through strengthening and expanding older persons structures to increase their inclusion in various COVID-19 and humanitarian services in Juba, South Sudan where high numbers of COVID-19 infections have been recorded.

title.narrative: Strengthening COVID-19 emergency response for vulnerable older women and men in Idlib in NW Syria

description.narrative: The project prioritises prevention, awareness raising and community sensitization focus that will help mitigate the impact of a COVID-19 outbreak when it materializes. It will focus on particularly vulnerable groups such as older women and men including older people with disabilities. Community awareness raising activities will be delivered through a mix of messaging modalities, such as use of social media, distribution of paper leaflets and flyers, use of mobile ambulances to deliver messages through loudspeaker, and training of volunteers and health workers on raising awareness and protection measure regarding COVID-19 and promoting behavioural change among the potentially affected population. For households deemed particularly vulnerable, hygiene kits for family use will be delivered, and this distribution will also be accompanied by appropriate messaging and delivery of information. A system will be established to ensure the maintenance of social contact with older people who might be isolated using phone calls, text messages and radio. Provision of awareness raising and information on COVID-19 will be made accessible to different groups of people, including older people, including older people with disabilities, through appropriate language, communication materials and age- friendly and relevant messaging. Strategies will be developed to provide Psychosocial Support for older people, including those with disabilities remotely, through training of professional counsellors and delivered through radio, telephone calls or other remote mechanisms.

title.narrative: Inclusive COVID-19 response to Older persons, people with disability and vulnerable persons in North Uganda, West Nile and Karamoja Sub Regions.

description.narrative: The proposed project will focus on increasing resilience of older persons and school going children under their care to respond to the impact of COVID-19 pandemic and government restrictions, through strengthening protection and increasing access to WASH facilities at community level. The project will conduct a rapid capacity building campaign through sensitization and access to age appropriate and ease to use IEC materials to communities focussing on older persons on appropriate COVID-19 pandemic prevention, mitigation and response mechanisms as per the Ministry of Health guidelines and in line with the national COVID-19 response policy 2020. It will procure and distribute PPE to10,000 beneficiaries working closely with the district local governments, other institution where communities gather like churches, schools and mosques. We will procure and distribute temperature guns, hand sanitizers, liquid soap and install hand washing facilities at 125 facilities across the sub region.

title.narrative: ACCESS IV: Provision of multi-sectoral humanitarian assistance to conflict-affected populations in Eastern Ukraine

description.narrative: This Action builds on ACCESS Consortium experience, and the sectoral and geographical synergies of the three phases, to further address the umanitarian needs of the most vulnerable conflict-affectedvpopulations living in eastern Ukraine. Overall, the Action aims to benefit 77,729 (38,614 direct and 39,115 indirect) in Luhansk and Donetsk Oblast – Government and Non-Government controlled areas and 179 organizations provide multi-sectoral humanitarian assistance in critical emergency areas including; protection, health (including mental health and psychosocial support), WASH, shelter rehabilitation and winterization, covid-19 response, and multipurpose cash and vouchers to meet food and other basic needs in line with the identified priorities and response strategies of the 2020 DG ECHO HIP for Ukraine and the 2019-2020 Multi-year Humanitarian Response Plan (MYHRP). Furthermore, the Action broadens the previous three phases focus on four protection mainstreaming principles of meaningful access, safety and dignity, local participation/empowerment, and accountability by including measures to ensure age and disability inclusion - key concerns given the demographics of eastern Ukraine. Protection mainstreaming resources already established in ACCESS will remain active. Interventions will be augmented by the Action's contribution to strengthening response analysis and coordination through enhancing information management, and by national and international advocacy to inform response planning and implementation. By working with a strong network of local actors, the Consortium continues to contribute to strengthening capacities within Ukraine. The Action is implemented by a Consortium of four international and one national organizations operating in Ukraine: People in Need (PIN), as lead agency, with Medicos del Mundo (MdM), ACTED - in partnership with IMPACT Initiatives, HelpAge International (HAI), and Right to Protection (R2P).

title.narrative: Strengthening COVID-19 emergency response for conflict affected vulnerable and disabled older women and men in settlements located in the 5km zone in the GCAs locations of Donetsk and Luhansk Oblasts.

description.narrative: This project builds on previous and current multi-sectoral humanitarian interventions implemented by HelpAge International in Ukraine, to provide direct support to conflict affected older women and men, including those with disabilities, who are most at risk from the effects of COVID-19, through Psychosocial Support (PSS ) activities, Home-Based Care (HBC) for the most vulnerable households, the provision of COVID-19 adapted hygiene kits and food packages, and the dissemination of age-friendly information materials on how to combat the virus. The home-based care (HBC) activities will be implemented by existing HelpAge trained community-based volunteers, including in COVID-19 awareness and safety measures, who will safely conduct outreach visits while minimizing social contact and incorporating do-no harm practices to at least 2000 vulnerable older women and men, and persons with disabilities located in 17 of the 53 prioritised settlements of Donetsk and Luhansk. These locations are considered to be in high need and be the most isolated and hard to reach areas with limited services and infrastructure, near to the line of contact. The HBC services provides support to promote greater levels of Independent living capacity, reduce isolation, improve awareness/understanding on COVID-19 and to facilitate the distribution of Hygiene Kits and Food Packages. Through these activities and by using a multi sectoral approach addressing protection, health and nutrition and WASH concerns, older people and persons with disabilities will be identified and their critical needs supported through appropriate interventions.

title.narrative: Support Viet Nam organizations in COVID-19 Preparedness and Response for older persons

description.narrative: 1. To protect older persons and their caregivers from COVID-19 transmission by providing personnel of Social Protection centers, community personnel and caregivers of local Associations of the Elderly (AE) and community-based Intergenerational Self-Help Clubs (ISHC), who are providing social protection and care services at the older persons' homes, in high-risk areas with personal protective equipment (gloves, masks and protective lenses), essential hygiene and health care item (hand sanitizers, thermometers).
2. To raise awareness and communicate on Covid-19 and promote community engagement by developing and distributing related IEC materials to communities, older persons and their caregivers.

3. To strengthen capacity of local Associations of the Elderly (AE) and community-based Intergenerational Self-Help Clubs (ISHC) on COVID-19 prevention, response and recovery intervention by developing of manuals and guidelines and providing training for community personnel, ISHC Board Members and caregivers.

The programme works with national partners in 13 cities and provinces to protect older people and their caregivers from the impact of Covid-19. Its activities aim to make care-giving activities in homes more Covid-secure, raise community awareness of the pandemic and prevention measures and strengthen the capacity of local associations for older people to implement safer community activities.

Jul-Sep20 Expenditure

This task order is part of the DID programme's Covid-19 response portfolio. The DID Covid-19 response and recovery coordination platform was established with the vital mandate to coordinate the response while looking at opportunities for joint awareness and advocacy campaigning, sharing of resources, production of evidence-based disability inclusive learning and development of sharing mechanisms to influence policies, promoting research uptake and coordinating disability-inclusive Covid-19 response.

title.narrative: DID TO13 - Strengthening systems for the enrolment, retention and support of children with disabilities at primary level of mainstream education in Bangladesh - Phase 1

description.narrative:
This task order has been developed by adapting the original planning for an inclusive education task order in Bangladesh focussing on children with disabilities out of primary school - especially those with severe and multiple disabilities. Acknowledging the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the school closures for a big part of the school year 2020 the approach for 2021 is adapted to support the return of children with disabilities into school who were previously enrolled, during the COVID-19 recovery in the education sector in Bangladesh.
While adapting to the new environment in the education sector, the initial plan for 2021 to identify children who have never been enrolled due to severe and multiple disabilities and start work with families and communities to promote their enrolment in schools in 2022 will still go ahead. Experience from consortium partners’ inclusive education projects in other countries has showed that in the current scenario it is likely that children who have never been enrolled at school will likely experience increased levels of exclusion and be the last ones to go to schools until the situation normalises. In this task order options to address this, including a shift of focus towards a community-based model of support and education at home, will be explored, to inform the strategy for phase 2 from 2022 onwards.
Within this task order the groundwork of the cooperation with the PENDA programme on the planned impact evaluation - focussing on phase 2 from January 2022 onwards - will be laid.

description.narrative: Around one-fifth of young people worldwide were not in employment, education or training, prior to COVID-19. The Skills for Prosperity Programme tackles this global challenge by supporting education and skills systems across nine middle income countries in South East Asia, Latin America and Africa. Working hand in hand with national governments, industry and the education and skills sector, Skills for Prosperity seeks to improve the life chances of marginalised groups, including young people and women. It aims to do this by equipping them with skills fit for the future, thereby helping to improve the prosperity of individuals, communities and economies. This is a flagship global skills programme for the UK government.

title.narrative: Education Research in Conflict and Protracted Crisis (ERICC)

description.narrative: To strengthen policies and programming for education in conflict and protracted crisis. This programme will improve learning outcomes of the most marginalised children. It responds to a demand for rigorous, policy-relevant research in six focal countries on "what works" to deliver education in these contexts. The UK will work with partners to disseminate evidence and promote uptake, and provide technical expertise and operational support to DFID country offices. It is expected that initial technical call-down support for governments will have a focus on Covid-19. This programme will have a focus on equity, and directly supports the manifesto commitment on girls' education,

title.narrative: Bangladesh - Rohingya Response and National Resilience Programme (RRNRP)

description.narrative: To improve protection and quality of humanitarian assistance for the Rohingya population living in refugee camps in southern Bangladesh, so that they can live full and meaningful lives. This to be done peacefully living alongside host communities, for whom the impacts of the crisis need to be reduced and development opportunities provided. The programme marks a shift in FCDO’s (Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office) response to the crisis by providing longer term, predictable support to address the needs of both refugees and host communities. Whilst the focus will be on sustaining and improving the humanitarian operation through provision of quality basic services, there will be a specific focus on stimulating the economy, rehabilitating the environment, and promoting stability for both populations’ benefit. The programme aim to support COVID-19 and early emergency recovery support for national resilience by providing support to the national COVID-19 and disaster response.

title.narrative: Getting children ready to learn and thrive - Research into implementing effective and quality Early Childhood Development at scale

description.narrative: The THRIVE Early Childhood Development research programme will deliver research on how to implement effective ECD interventions at scale in LMICs. Through an innovative model of research co-designed and aligned to DFID country programmes, THRIVE will support four DFID bilateral programmes to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of ECD interventions emdedded in their education and human development programmes, and commission globally-relevant research into optimal ECD service delivery and scale up strategies. Through the proposed COVID-19 pivot, the programme will generate real time evidence on impact of Covid-19 on young children's learning and development, and test at scale innovation on approaches to mitigate the crisis of learning and care. This programme directly responds to the manifesto commitment on girls' education.

description.narrative: This programme will secure UK leadership to produce global goods in education, catalyse mulitlateral, bilateral and philanthropic spend to address learning poverty, and convene global and national policy reform events across 27 DFID countries. Funding will support research projects which respond to the urgent need to understand how to bring girls back into the classroom following Covid-19 school closures, and informs systems change to ensure all children can learn once they return to school. This programme directly responds to the manifesto commitment on girls' education.
